pullrequest.title: Add a new semi-supervised test case

content.raw:
I'd seriously consider changing the "simplesemi" folder name to "simplesemisupervised". It makes everything much clearer at a glace what it's testing (though the current name isn't all that bad).

Also how did you select your semi-supervised areas in your test/simplesemi/semi-label.bed? How do we know that this semi-supervision produces a desired/correct segmentation? How does it differ from simpleseg? If it's not at all obvious how the semi-supervised .bed regions alters the output perhaps consider changing the supervised training regions. As an example - maybe supervise segway to try to do the opposite of the results from simpleseg?
content.html:
I'd seriously consider changing the "simplesemi" folder name to "simplesemisupervised". It makes everything much clearer at a glace what it's testing (though the current name isn't all that bad).

Also how did you select your semi-supervised areas in your test/simplesemi/semi-label.bed? How do we know that this semi-supervision produces a desired/correct segmentation? How does it differ from simpleseg? If it's not at all obvious how the semi-supervised .bed regions alters the output perhaps consider changing the supervised training regions. As an example - maybe supervise segway to try to do the opposite of the results from simpleseg?

pullrequest.title: Add a new semi-supervised test case

content.raw:
Region were picked by myself randomly. I wonder if we really have to be serious about selecting a good region since we have been always using dummy data in testcases. Besides I think the idea here for simplesemisupervised test case is to make sure any future modification on segway will still be consistent with the previous version in terms of output under semi-supervised case, unless we clearly specifies changing it (which will result in modification of the test case also). So I don't see why we need to link its resulting segmentation to the unsupervised case (simpleseg) as long as we have use the --sermisupervised functionality in the test case.

I agree with changing the folder name.
content.html:
Region were picked by myself randomly. I wonder if we really have to be serious about selecting a good region since we have been always using dummy data in testcases. Besides I think the idea here for simplesemisupervised test case is to make sure any future modification on segway will still be consistent with the previous version in terms of output under semi-supervised case, unless we clearly specifies changing it (which will result in modification of the test case also). So I don't see why we need to link its resulting segmentation to the unsupervised case (simpleseg) as long as we have use the --sermisupervised functionality in the test case.

I agree with changing the folder name.

pullrequest.title: Add a new semi-supervised test case

content.raw: The dummy data was selected for simplicity and being able to produce results that could be manually inspected for "good enough" results. There should be a way of noticing if the supervision if at all has an effect. This testcase, for example, may not catch the case where if a new bug was introduced and `--semisupervised` was somehow disabled. Admittedly that's probably not the case currently (the supervision probably has some influence over the final results) but the testcase itself is not convincing of that.
content.html: The dummy data was selected for simplicity and being able to produce results that could be manually inspected for "good enough" results. There should be a way of noticing if the supervision if at all has an effect. This testcase, for example, may not catch the case where if a new bug was introduced and --semisupervised was somehow disabled. Admittedly that's probably not the case currently (the supervision probably has some influence over the final results) but the testcase itself is not convincing of that.

pullrequest.title: Add a new semi-supervised test case

content.raw:
If all we want is [semisupervised has an effect] not [semisupervised has a clear effect make it different from unsupervised case which is explained by the semisupervised label we use] then it can be easily detected since the params.params of the semisupervised would be different (and it is different) from the unsupervised case. 

simpleseg:
https://bitbucket.org/Tamaki_Sakura/segway/src/97d309d8ee69ec0717a785eb6df1f24bf3f5c788/test/simpleseg/touchstone/traindir/params/params.params?at=semi_test_case

simplesemisupervised:
https://bitbucket.org/Tamaki_Sakura/segway/src/97d309d8ee69ec0717a785eb6df1f24bf3f5c788/test/simplesemi/touchstone/traindir/params/params.params?at=semi_test_case
content.html:
If all we want is [semisupervised has an effect] not [semisupervised has a clear effect make it different from unsupervised case which is explained by the semisupervised label we use] then it can be easily detected since the params.params of the semisupervised would be different (and it is different) from the unsupervised case.

simpleseg: https://bitbucket.org/Tamaki_Sakura/segway/src/97d309d8ee69ec0717a785eb6df1f24bf3f5c788/test/simpleseg/touchstone/traindir/params/params.params?at=semi_test_case

pullrequest.title: Add a new semi-supervised test case

content.raw:
Yes the testcase does definitely prove that semi-supervision has produced different results. The big question is if it's possible to arrange the supervision so that the results would be more or less verifiable (the touchstone results themselves). It's my impression we would like to have a touchstone (or gold standard) that demonstrability proves that the supervision is working as intended and not necessarily that it's *only* producing some sort of different result.

@hoffman do you have any thoughts about this?
content.html:
Yes the testcase does definitely prove that semi-supervision has produced different results. The big question is if it's possible to arrange the supervision so that the results would be more or less verifiable (the touchstone results themselves). It's my impression we would like to have a touchstone (or gold standard) that demonstrability proves that the supervision is working as intended and not necessarily that it's only producing some sort of different result.

@hoffman do you have any thoughts about this?

pullrequest.title: Add a new semi-supervised test case

content.raw: OK now I see what you mean. Yes its possible, although it ain't easy to design a sample like that and I'm not entirely sure if this would be very useful.

pullrequest.title: Add a new semi-supervised test case

content.raw: Yes, Eric pretty much has it. The `data` test was the original smoke test based on some random sample of real data, but someone designed `simpleseg` so that it would be easily verifiable. This test should be verifiable. How about taking the same random seed as `simpleseg` but picking something that would ordinarily be defined as 1 in the unsupervised case and assigning it to 0 instead via supervision label? Just assign one whole region as 0 this way.
content.html: Yes, Eric pretty much has it. The data test was the original smoke test based on some random sample of real data, but someone designed simpleseg so that it would be easily verifiable. This test should be verifiable. How about taking the same random seed as simpleseg but picking something that would ordinarily be defined as 1 in the unsupervised case and assigning it to 0 instead via supervision label? Just assign one whole region as 0 this way.

pullrequest.title: Add a new semi-supervised test case

content.raw:
I realize there is actually a training error in simpleseg, would it be a good idea to make the semisupervised label to be that training error period?

https://bitbucket.org/Tamaki_Sakura/segway/src/97d309d8ee69ec0717a785eb6df1f24bf3f5c788/test/simpleseg/touchstone/identifydir/viterbi/viterbi0.bed?at=semi_test_case

0-2000 and 4000-6000 are treated as 1, where 0-1000 is different from 1000-2000. Assigning 0-1000 and 4000-5000 a semisupervised label 0 will fix this problem.
content.html:
I realize there is actually a training error in simpleseg, would it be a good idea to make the semisupervised label to be that training error period?

https://bitbucket.org/Tamaki_Sakura/segway/src/97d309d8ee69ec0717a785eb6df1f24bf3f5c788/test/simpleseg/touchstone/identifydir/viterbi/viterbi0.bed?at=semi_test_case

0-2000 and 4000-6000 are treated as 1, where 0-1000 is different from 1000-2000. Assigning 0-1000 and 4000-5000 a semisupervised label 0 will fix this problem.

pullrequest.title: Add a new semi-supervised test case

content.raw: This should produce a .genomedata file that isn't called simpleseg. It should probably produce a genomedata archive called "simplesemisupervised.genomedata" or something similar. This file should be used and referenced in the run.sh.
content.html: This should produce a .genomedata file that isn't called simpleseg. It should probably produce a genomedata archive called "simplesemisupervised.genomedata" or something similar. This file should be used and referenced in the run.sh.

pullrequest.title: Add a new semi-supervised test case

content.raw:
I believe the discrepancies in the segmentation was investigated and it was found that the way the segmentation occurred it managed to group two clusters into 1 (hence the doubling up on region label '1' and the seemingly absent region label '0'). I also believe that this is a result of the chosen seed. The most important part about all of this is it was investigated and found to be acceptable so it's not a real "bug".

I agree it would be an okay idea to try to have the supervised case to demonstrably put the obvious 4 categories/regions into 4 distinct labels. The only other part of that would be to make sure the label numbers are effectively changed as well (e.g. labels 2 and 3 in simpleseg should not be labelled '2' and '3' respectfully in the supervised case).
content.html:
I believe the discrepancies in the segmentation was investigated and it was found that the way the segmentation occurred it managed to group two clusters into 1 (hence the doubling up on region label '1' and the seemingly absent region label '0'). I also believe that this is a result of the chosen seed. The most important part about all of this is it was investigated and found to be acceptable so it's not a real "bug".

I agree it would be an okay idea to try to have the supervised case to demonstrably put the obvious 4 categories/regions into 4 distinct labels. The only other part of that would be to make sure the label numbers are effectively changed as well (e.g. labels 2 and 3 in simpleseg should not be labelled '2' and '3' respectfully in the supervised case).

pullrequest.title: Add a new semi-supervised test case

content.raw:
Can you label this 3 instead? The only reason I'm suggesting is this would be a better demonstration of supervision since this testcase only "fixes" the segmentation from the unsupervised case of simpleseg.

If we could label this differently (e.g. 3,0,1,2) from "correct" simpleseg case (which is 0,1,2,3) and get all 4 labels output that would be more than sufficient to show that supervision is working correctly.
content.html:
Can you label this 3 instead? The only reason I'm suggesting is this would be a better demonstration of supervision since this testcase only "fixes" the segmentation from the unsupervised case of simpleseg.

If we could label this differently (e.g. 3,0,1,2) from "correct" simpleseg case (which is 0,1,2,3) and get all 4 labels output that would be more than sufficient to show that supervision is working correctly.

label it 3 unfortunately will make the result wrong.

chr1    2000    3000    2       1000    .       2000    3000    117,112,179

pullrequest.title: Add a new semi-supervised test case

content.raw:
How is this the fault of the initial parameter? Aren't you using the same seed across runs?
If setting the label to '0' gives the (0,1,2,3) pattern but setting the label to '3' gives the (3,1,2,3) pattern I think something else is amiss. Do you have any ideas?

I don't think is necessarily intended behavior. Can you even produce a 4 label segmentation with different seeds/instances and having the label '3'?
content.html:
How is this the fault of the initial parameter? Aren't you using the same seed across runs? If setting the label to '0' gives the (0,1,2,3) pattern but setting the label to '3' gives the (3,1,2,3) pattern I think something else is amiss. Do you have any ideas?

I don't think is necessarily intended behavior. Can you even produce a 4 label segmentation with different seeds/instances and having the label '3'?

pullrequest.title: Add a new semi-supervised test case

content.raw:
Because the mean in the input.master for different labels are different, for the current seed we have.

Basically it will not force vector mean (0.57, 0.48) to be close to the mean in region 0~1000/4000~5000, instead it will force (0.51, 0.57).

```
0 mean_seg0_subseg0_testtrack1 1 0.571728495846
1 mean_seg0_subseg0_testtrack2 1 0.482009675214
2 mean_seg1_subseg0_testtrack1 1 0.393569676591
3 mean_seg1_subseg0_testtrack2 1 0.524263233453
4 mean_seg2_subseg0_testtrack1 1 0.539103684627
5 mean_seg2_subseg0_testtrack2 1 0.452877599219
6 mean_seg3_subseg0_testtrack1 1 0.508957638027
7 mean_seg3_subseg0_testtrack2 1 0.57080277882
```
content.html:
Because the mean in the input.master for different labels are different, for the current seed we have.

Basically it will not force vector mean (0.57, 0.48) to be close to the mean in region 0~1000/4000~5000, instead it will force (0.51, 0.57).

0 mean_seg0_subseg0_testtrack1 1 0.571728495846
1 mean_seg0_subseg0_testtrack2 1 0.482009675214
2 mean_seg1_subseg0_testtrack1 1 0.393569676591
3 mean_seg1_subseg0_testtrack2 1 0.524263233453
4 mean_seg2_subseg0_testtrack1 1 0.539103684627
5 mean_seg2_subseg0_testtrack2 1 0.452877599219
6 mean_seg3_subseg0_testtrack1 1 0.508957638027
7 mean_seg3_subseg0_testtrack2 1 0.57080277882

content.raw: The initial means change depending on the supervision label number?
content.html: The initial means change depending on the supervision label number?

pullrequest.title: Add a new semi-supervised test case

content.raw:
No. Initial means for each label does not change. 

However, when changing the supervision label number, the supervision region are refer to different label, thus different initial mean now. 

That's kind of inevitable but doesn't matter unless we're doing something like Pull Request #25 which had been suspended.
content.html:
No. Initial means for each label does not change.

However, when changing the supervision label number, the supervision region are refer to different label, thus different initial mean now.

That's kind of inevitable but doesn't matter unless we're doing something like Pull Request #25 which had been suspended.

pullrequest.title: Add a new semi-supervised test case

content.raw: I'm still trying to understand this. Can you demonstrate or show how you get different initial means between changing supervision regions?
content.html: I'm still trying to understand this. Can you demonstrate or show how you get different initial means between changing supervision regions?

pullrequest.title: Add a new semi-supervised test case

content.raw:
If the supervision region is assigned to label 0, it's inital mean will be the same as the inital mean for unsupervised region have label 0, i.e. the vector (0.57, 0.48)

If the supervision region is assigned to label 3, it's inital mean will be the same as the inital mean for unsupervised region have label 3, i.e. the vector (0.51, 0.57)
content.html:
If the supervision region is assigned to label 0, it's inital mean will be the same as the inital mean for unsupervised region have label 0, i.e. the vector (0.57, 0.48)

If the supervision region is assigned to label 3, it's inital mean will be the same as the inital mean for unsupervised region have label 3, i.e. the vector (0.51, 0.57)

pullrequest.title: Add a new semi-supervised test case

content.raw:
I just had a discussion with @hoffman about this issue and he agreed it's probably best to simply run segway setting the seed using the `$RANDOM` bash variable (and echoing it so you can see what it is) until you get better initial unsupervised means to be used in the supervision.

Simply put, try to run segway setting the seed to `$RANDOM` until you can get a good 4 label segmentation that's different from "0,1,2,3".
content.html:
I just had a discussion with @hoffman about this issue and he agreed it's probably best to simply run segway setting the seed using the $RANDOM bash variable (and echoing it so you can see what it is) until you get better initial unsupervised means to be used in the supervision.

Simply put, try to run segway setting the seed to $RANDOM until you can get a good 4 label segmentation that's different from "0,1,2,3".
